naam_2117.name: Naam
naam_2117.bio: Pleasantness, one of the three sons of Caleb, the son of Jephunneh ([1 Chr. 4:15](/1chr#1Chr.4.15)).

naamah_2118.name: Naamah (Zillah also had a son)
naamah_2118.bio: The daughter of Lamech and Zillah ([Gen. 4](/gen#Gen.4): 22).

naamah_2119.name: Naamah (The daughter of the king of Ammon)
naamah_2119.bio: The daughter of the king of Ammon, one of the wives of Solomon, the only one who appears to have borne him a son, viz., Rehoboam ([1 Kings 14:21](/1kgs#1Kgs.14.21), [31](/1kgs#1Kgs.14.31)).

naaman_2122.name: Naaman (A member of the tribe of Benjamin. The g)
naaman_2122.bio: Pleasantness, a Syrian, the commander of the armies of Benhadad II. in the time of Joram, king of Israel. He was afflicted with leprosy; and when the little Hebrew slave-girl that waited on his wife told her of a prophet in Samaria who could cure her master, he obtained a letter from Benhadad and proceeded with it to Joram.

naaman_2123.name: Naaman (commander of the army of the king of Ara)

naarah_2124.name: Naarah
naarah_2124.bio: A girl, the second of Ashur’s two wives, of the tribe of Judah ([1 Chr. 4:5](/1chr#1Chr.4.5), [6](/1chr#1Chr.4.6)).

naarai_2125.name: Naarai
naarai_2125.bio: Youthful, a military chief in David’s army ([1 Chr. 11:37](/1chr#1Chr.11.37)), called also Paarai ([2 Sam. 23:35](/2sam#2Sam.23.35)).

nabal_2126.name: Nabal
nabal_2126.bio: Foolish, a descendant of Caleb who dwelt at Maon ([1 Sam. 25](/1sam#1Sam.25)), the modern Main, 7 miles south-east of Hebron. He was “very great, and he had 3,000 sheep and 1,000 goats...but the man was churlish and evil in his doings.” During his wanderings David came into that district, and hearing that Nabal was about to shear his sheep, he sent ten of his young men to ask “whatsoever cometh unto thy hand for thy servants.” Nabal insultingly resented the demand, saying, “Who is David, and who is the son of Jesse?” ([1 Sam.

naboth_2127.name: Naboth
naboth_2127.bio: Fruits, “the Jezreelite,” was the owner of a portion of ground on the eastern slope of the hill of Jezreel ([2 Kings 9:25](/2kgs#2Kgs.9.25), [26](/2kgs#2Kgs.9.26)). This small “plat of ground” seems to have been all he possessed. It was a vineyard, and lay “hard by the palace of Ahab” ([1 Kings 21:1](/1kgs#1Kgs.21.1), [2](/1kgs#1Kgs.21.2)), who greatly coveted it.

nadab_2128.name: Nadab (Exod 6:23; 24:1)
nadab_2128.bio: The eldest of Aaron’s four sons ([Ex. 6:23](/exod#Exod.6.23); [Num. 3:2](/num#Num.3.2)).

nadab_2129.name: Nadab (the second king of Israel)
nadab_2129.bio: The son and successor of Jeroboam, the king of Israel ([1 Kings 14:20](/1kgs#1Kgs.14.20)). While engaged with all Israel in laying siege to Gibbethon, a town of southern Dan ([Josh. 19:44](/josh#Josh.19.44)), a conspiracy broke out in his army, and he was slain by Baasha ([1 Kings 15:25-28](/1kgs#1Kgs.15.25)), after a reign of two years (B.C.

nadab_2130.name: Nadab (son of Shammai)
nadab_2130.bio: One of the sons of Shammai in the tribe of Judah ([1 Chr. 2:28](/1chr#1Chr.2.28), [30](/1chr#1Chr.2.30)).

naharai_2135.name: Naharai
naharai_2135.bio: Snorer, a Berothite, one of David’s heroes, and armour-bearer of Joab ([1 Chr. 11:39](/1chr#1Chr.11.39)).

nahash_2136.name: Nahash (the Ammonite. king of the Ammonites)
nahash_2136.bio: King of the Ammonites in the time of Saul. The inhabitants of Jabesh-Gilead having been exposed to great danger from Nahash, sent messengers to Gibeah to inform Saul of their extremity. He promptly responded to the call, and gathering together an army he marched against Nahash.

nahash_2138.name: Nahash (Led Ammonites against Saul)
nahash_2138.bio: The father of Amasa, who was commander-in-chief of Abasolom’s army ([2 Sam. 17:25](/2sam#2Sam.17.25)). Jesse’s wife had apparently been first married to this man, to whom she bore Abigail and Zeruiah, who were thus David’s sisters, but only on the mother’s side ([1 Chr.

nahath_2140.name: Nahath (Levite)
nahath_2140.bio: A Levite, one of the overseers of the sacred offerings of the temple ([2 Chr. 31:13](/2chr#2Chr.31.13)).

nahath_2146.name: Nahath (duke of Edom)
nahath_2146.bio: One of the four sons of Reuel, the son of Esau ([Gen. 36:13](/gen#Gen.36.13), [17](/gen#Gen.36.17)).

nahbi_2141.name: Nahbi
nahbi_2141.bio: Hidden, one of the twelve spies sent out to explore the land of Canaan ([Num. 13:14](/num#Num.13.14)).

nahor_2142.name: Nahor (elder brother of Abraham)
nahor_2142.bio: The father of Terah, who was the father of Abraham ([Gen. 11:22-25](/gen#Gen.11.22); [Luke 3:34](/luke#Luke.3.34)).

nahor_2143.name: Nahor (father of Abram)
nahor_2143.bio: A son of Terah, and elder brother of Abraham ([Gen. 11:26](/gen#Gen.11.26), [27](/gen#Gen.11.27); [Josh. 24:2](/josh#Josh.24.2), R.V.).

nahshon_2144.name: Nahshon
nahshon_2144.bio: Sorcerer, the son of Aminadab, and prince of the children of Judah at the time of the first numbering of the tribes in the wilderness ([Ex. 6:23](/exod#Exod.6.23)). His sister Elisheba was the wife of Aaron.

naomi_2147.name: Naomi
naomi_2147.bio: Bitter; sad, a symbolical name which Naomi gave to herself because of her misfortunes ([Ruth 1:20](/ruth#Ruth.1.20)).

naphtali_2149.name: Naphtali
naphtali_2149.bio: My wrestling, the fifth son of Jacob. His mother was Bilhah, Rachel’s handmaid ([Gen. 30:8](/gen#Gen.30.8)).

naphtuhim_2150.name: Naphtuhim
naphtuhim_2150.bio: A Hamitic tribe descended from Mizraim ([Gen. 10:13](/gen#Gen.10.13)). Others identify this word with Napata, the name of the city and territory on the southern frontier of Mizraim, the modern Meroe, at the great bend of the Nile at Soudan.

narcissus_2151.name: Narcissus
narcissus_2151.bio: Daffodil, a Roman whom Paul salutes ([Rom. 16:11](/rom#Rom.16.11)). He is supposed to have been the private secretary of the emperor Claudius.

nathan_2152.name: Nathan (son of Jehoiada)
nathan_2152.bio: A son of David, by Bathsheba ([2 Sam. 5:14](/2sam#2Sam.5.14)), whose name appears in the genealogy of Mary, the mother of our Lord ([Luke 3:31](/luke#Luke.3.31)).

nathan_2153.name: Nathan (son of Hagri)
nathan_2153.bio: A prophet in the reigns of David and Solomon ([2 Chr. 9:29](/2chr#2Chr.9.29)). He is first spoken of in connection with the arrangements David made for the building of the temple ([2 Sam.

nathan_2154.name: Nathan (Attai was the father of Nathan)

nathan_2155.name: Nathan (the Jerahmeelite)
nathan_2155.bio: A prophet in the reigns of David and Solomon ([2 Chr. 9:29](/2chr#2Chr.9.29)). He is first spoken of in connection with the arrangements David made for the building of the temple ([2 Sam.

nathanael_2158.name: Nathanael
nathanael_2158.bio: Given or gift of God, one of our Lord’s disciples, “of Cana in Galilee” ([John 21:2](/john#John.21.2)). He was “an Israelite indeed, in whom was no guile” (1:47, 48). His name occurs only in the Gospel of John, who in his list of the disciples never mentions Bartholomew, with whom he has consequently been identified.

nebajoth_2164.name: Nebajoth
nebajoth_2164.bio: Ishmael’s eldest son ([Gen. 25:13](/gen#Gen.25.13)), and the prince of an Israelitish tribe (16). He had a sister, Mahalath, who was one of Esau’s wives ([Gen.

nebat_2165.name: Nebat
nebat_2165.bio: Sight; aspect, the father of Jeroboam, the king of Israel ([1 Kings 11:26](/1kgs#1Kgs.11.26), etc.).

nebuchadnezzar_2167.name: Nebuchadnezzar
nebuchadnezzar_2167.bio: In the Babylonian orthography Nabu-kudur-uzur, which means “Nebo, protect the crown!” or the “frontiers.” In an inscription he styles himself “Nebo’s favourite.” He was the son and successor of Nabopolassar, who delivered Babylon from its dependence on Assyria and laid Nineveh in ruins. He was the greatest and most powerful of all the Babylonian kings. He married the daughter of Cyaxares, and thus the Median and Babylonian dynasties were united.

nebushasban_2168.name: Nebushasban
nebushasban_2168.bio: Adorer of Nebo, or Nebo saves me, the “Rabsaris,” or chief chamberlain, of the court of Babylon. He was one of those whom the king sent to release Jeremiah from prison in Jerusalem ([Jer. 39:13](/jer#Jer.39.13)).

nebuzar-adan_2169.name: Nebuzar-adan
nebuzar-adan_2169.bio: “the captain of the guard,” in rank next to the king, who appears prominent in directing affairs at the capture of Jerusalem ([2 Kings 25:8-20](/2kgs#2Kgs.25.8); [Jer. 39:11](/jer#Jer.39.11); [40:2-5](/jer#Jer.40.2)). He showed kindness toward Jeremiah, as commanded by Nebuchadnezzar (40:1).

nedabiah_2170.name: Nedabiah
nedabiah_2170.bio: Moved of Jehovah, one of the sons of Jeconiah ([1 Chr. 3:18](/1chr#1Chr.3.18)).

nehemiah_2172.name: Nehemiah (of the tribe of Judah)
nehemiah_2172.bio: The son of Hachaliah ([Neh. 1:1](/neh#Neh.1.1)), and probably of the tribe of Judah. His family must have belonged to Jerusalem ([Neh.

nehushta_2174.name: Nehushta
nehushta_2174.bio: Copper, the daughter of Elnathan of Jerusalem, and the wife of Jehoiakin ([2 Kings 24:8](/2kgs#2Kgs.24.8)), king of Judah.

nekoda_2176.name: Nekoda (The sons of Midian were Ephah)

nemuel_2177.name: Nemuel
nemuel_2177.bio: A Reubenite, a son of Eliab, and brother of Dathan and Abiram ([Num. 26:9](/num#Num.26.9)).

ner_2181.name: Ner
ner_2181.bio: Light, the father of Kish ([1 Chr. 8:33](/1chr#1Chr.8.33)). [1 Sam.

nergal-sharezer_2183.name: Nergal-sharezer
nergal-sharezer_2183.bio: Another of the “princes,” who bore the title of “Rabmag.” He was one of those who were sent to release Jeremiah from prison ([Jer. 39:13](/jer#Jer.39.13)) by “the captain of the guard.” He was a Babylonian grandee of high rank. From profane history and the inscriptions, we are led to conclude that he was the Neriglissar who murdered Evil-merodach, the son of Nebuchadnezzar, and succeeded him on the throne of Babylon (B.C.

nethaneel_2188.name: Nethaneel (son of Zuar)
nethaneel_2188.bio: The son of Zuar, chief of the tribe of Issachar at the Exodus ([Num. 1:8](/num#Num.1.8); [2:5](/num#Num.2.5)).

nethaneel_2190.name: Nethaneel (son of Zuar)
nethaneel_2190.bio: A priest who blew the trumpet before the ark when it was brought up to Jerusalem ([1 Chr. 15:24](/1chr#1Chr.15.24)).

nethaneel_2192.name: Nethaneel (Son of Obed-edom)
nethaneel_2192.bio: A temple porter, of the family of the Korhites ([1 Chr. 26:4](/1chr#1Chr.26.4)).

nethaneel_2193.name: Nethaneel (son of Zuar)
nethaneel_2193.bio: One of the “princes” appointed by Jehoshaphat to teach the law through the cities of Judah ([2 Chr. 17:7](/2chr#2Chr.17.7)).

nethaneel_2194.name: Nethaneel (who provided offerings for the Levites)
nethaneel_2194.bio: A chief Levite in the time of Josiah ([2 Chr. 35:9](/2chr#2Chr.35.9)).

nethaneel_2197.name: Nethaneel (trumpet bearer at Jerusalem)
nethaneel_2197.bio: A priest’s son who bore a trumpet at the dedication of the walls of Jerusalem ([Neh. 12:36](/neh#Neh.12.36)).

nethaniah_2200.name: Nethaniah (were certain Levites—Shemaiah)
nethaniah_2200.bio: A Levite sent by Jehoshaphat to teach the law ([2 Chr. 17:8](/2chr#2Chr.17.8)).

nicanor_2203.name: Nicanor
nicanor_2203.bio: conqueror, one of the seven deacons appointed in the apostolic Church ( Acts 6:1-6 ). Nothing further is known of him.

nicodemus_2204.name: Nicodemus
nicodemus_2204.bio: The people is victor, a Pharisee and a member of the Sanhedrin. He is first noticed as visiting Jesus by night ([John 3:1-21](/john#John.3.1)) for the purpose of learning more of his doctrines, which our Lord then unfolded to him, giving prominence to the necessity of being “born again.” He is next met with in the Sanhedrin (7:50-52), where he protested against the course they were taking in plotting against Christ. Once more he is mentioned as taking part in the preparation for the anointing and burial of the body of Christ ([John 19:39](/john#John.19.39)).

nicolas_2205.name: Nicolas
nicolas_2205.bio: the victory of the people, a proselyte of Antioch, one of the seven deacons ( Acts 6:5 ).

nimrod_2206.name: Nimrod
nimrod_2206.bio: Firm, a descendant of Cush, the son of Ham. He was the first who claimed to be a “mighty one in the earth.” Babel was the beginning of his kingdom, which he gradually enlarged ([Gen. 10:8-10](/gen#Gen.10.8)).

nimshi_2207.name: Nimshi
nimshi_2207.bio: Saved. Jehu was “the son of Jehoshaphat, the son of Nimshi” ([2 Kings 9:2](/2kgs#2Kgs.9.2); comp. [1 Kings 19:16](/1kgs#1Kgs.19.16)).

noadiah_2208.name: Noadiah (A Levite)
noadiah_2208.bio: A Levite who returned from Babylon ([Ezra 8:33](/ezra#Ezra.8.33)).

noadiah_2209.name: Noadiah (son of Binnui)
noadiah_2209.bio: A false prophetess who assisted Tobiah and Sanballat against the Jews ([Neh. 6:14](/neh#Neh.6.14)). Being bribed by them, she tried to stir up discontent among the inhabitants of Jerusalem, and so to embarrass Nehemiah in his great work of rebuilding the ruined walls of the city.

noah_2210.name: Noah (10th of the Pre-Flood Patriarchs)
noah_2210.bio: Rest, (Heb. Noah) the grandson of Methuselah ([Gen. 5:25-29](/gen#Gen.5.25)), who was for two hundred and fifty years contemporary with Adam, and the son of Lamech, who was about fifty years old at the time of Adam’s death.

noah_2211.name: Noah (daughter of Zelophehad)
noah_2211.bio: Rest, (Heb. Noah) the grandson of Methuselah ([Gen. 5:25-29](/gen#Gen.5.25)), who was for two hundred and fifty years contemporary with Adam, and the son of Lamech, who was about fifty years old at the time of Adam’s death.

nogah_2213.name: Nogah
nogah_2213.bio: Splendour, one of David’s sons, born at Jerusalem ([1 Chr. 3:7](/1chr#1Chr.3.7)).

nun_2214.name: Nun
nun_2214.bio: Beyond the fact that he was the father of Joshua nothing more is known of him ([Ex. 33:11](/exod#Exod.33.11)).
